messages: 6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (13:42): can I somehow search for comments to blog entries

d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:03): Didya win?
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:03): boyd: nah
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:03): bailed, anyway ... music was too loud, food too oily
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:03): anyway ... I saw that my port 80 rule was missing
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:04): I should get some food too actually
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:04): port 8000 was ok though but since I'm handling that via 80 and ajp worker threads.... 404 :(
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:04): Yeah, I wondered why I was getting a modem login screen :)
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:05): good thing I changed the default passwd
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:05): Yay!  I see your post :)
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:06): phew
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:09): ni ni
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:10): I think the problem with my dsl modem/router is that it will answer anything that's directed at the name associated with ppp0's IP address

0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:11): so from inside that box anything I request for port 80/8000/8009 to jmcp.homeunix.com will take me to the router itself rather than get redirected or dnat'd back to the designated internal box
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:14): Hmm... bummer
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:15): I have a similar (but slightly diff problem)
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:15): I have an internal DNS that I hacked to get around that
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:18): another friend just suggested bind views
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (14:19): I'm correct in assuming that converting a raidz to raidz2 won't be possible (any time soon) ?
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:20): boyd: something like this - http://www.isc.org/sw/bind/arm93/Bv9ARM.ch06.html#view_statement_grammar
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:20): Could be... but since I only query my DNS from inside I don't need view statements, I just present a fake root :)
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (14:23): Night all.
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:23): good nite
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:42): can somebody give his thoughts here on the following non techincal issues:
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:43): why is e1000 code (and some other NICS) is closed ?
6caff723a014fddb53dff9e10dd9e175 (14:43): prorietary code probably
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:43): because on linux, for example, the VERY SAME nic has an open source !
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:43): which is maintained by Intel !
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:43): so I underatnd that Intel DOES NOT YET
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:44): develop code for it's NICs on solaris
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:44): but why on earth is this code closed ? I assume SUN
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:44): SunnyDay: incorrect assumption to make
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:44): is developing this code
6caff723a014fddb53dff9e10dd9e175 (14:44): SunnyDay, you're more than welcome to write your own, no one will stop you.

0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:45): SunnyDay: the e1000g is Intel's. Just because they provide an OSS driver for linux does not mean that they are under any obligation whatsoever to do the same for (Open)Solaris
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (14:45): anyway, both sun and intel have both open and closed software mantained at the same time, I don't see this as a strange thing...
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:45): lasseoe, thnks, I am really thinking of writing some code for opensolaris; really ; not nics but USB wireless card (zd1211)
d91102e790545be0a09c1f715ac4926b (14:45): A USB wireless "card" would be a NIC, wouldn't it?
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (14:45): I don't want to judge if it's a good thing or a bad thing, but that's how those things go
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:46): jmcp, of course they are not obliged; but why they are not delivering it ?
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:46): SunnyDay: who is "they" ? Sun or Intel?
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:46): Intel can do whatever the heck they want, it's their product after all

12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:48): I am just curious why is the reason behind this because as I understand, once they deliver code for a NIC under linux, than delivering code for the same NIC for opensoalris cannot BY DEFINITION reveal anything new; am I right in this ?
6caff723a014fddb53dff9e10dd9e175 (14:48): SunnyDay, phone Intel and ask.
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:48): SunnyDay: there is no "By Definition" at work here
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:49): for a start, linux and Solaris have very different in-kernel interfaces and stability levels.
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:49): and BTW, if I am not wrong, Intel is not the onlyone it this resperct because other nic manufacturers also deliver NIC code as closed
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:49): for solaris
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:49): SunnyDay: SysKonnect have a GPL'd linux version and closed Solaris version of 'skge'
12f2c01b9e8d45fbd19e9b2e833940a7 (14:49): and open for linux
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:50): hi kimc
a02622c45eb22ef57d99330e2b404407 (14:50): wouldn't think some nic mfgs consider their driver code to be their 'ace in the hole'
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:51): probably
a02622c45eb22ef57d99330e2b404407 (14:51): ..gotta keep it a secret..
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:51): and nexus drivers too
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:51): which are an area that need documenting, incidentally
a02622c45eb22ef57d99330e2b404407 (14:54): speaking of network hardware, just installed a small gig switch purchased at the local Microcenter on Monday
a02622c45eb22ef57d99330e2b404407 (14:55): ~45000 Kbytes/sec on an ftp FreeBSD --> Opensolaris
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:56): not too bad
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (14:56): how about back the other way?
9f68ab96646717c9ac631f53a3130c5a (14:57): what was the limitting factor? presumably CPU on one or both ends?
a02622c45eb22ef57d99330e2b404407 (14:58): thats a great question
a02622c45eb22ef57d99330e2b404407 (14:58): what is an approach to determine the limiting factor..
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (15:00): kimc: dtrace
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (15:00): see how long system calls are taking, and also look at the io and fbt providers
94ece629302b8d297aacee2baaf20ac0 (15:04): SunnyDay: i gues syskonnect is to lasy to make a new driver for every linux-kernel vesion
94ece629302b8d297aacee2baaf20ac0 (15:06): and on solaris they can do it ones and it will work, so they dont need to mod and test it on every new version
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (15:07): coffman: part of what Sun might call the "value proposition" for Solaris
9f68ab96646717c9ac631f53a3130c5a (15:08): going into marketting, jmcp? :)
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (15:08): heckno
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (15:08): but I might get some contracting/consulting gigs in the next little while to present on ZFS and Dtrace to customers out this way
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (15:09): all at my very reasonable rates, of course :-)
a02622c45eb22ef57d99330e2b404407 (15:09): jmcp: what is your location ?
0e60fa2a21b13bc3d41902ac2acd28e3 (15:09): Sydney
